src:
SCJN desecha acción de inconstitucionalidad del INE contra Ley Bonilla
Por "notoria y manifiesta improcedencia", el ministro Fernando Franco desechó el recurso del INE
06 Nov 2019 by Carlos Lara | El Sol de México
Por "notoria y manifiesta improcedencia", Fernando Franco González Salas, ministro de la Suprema Corte de Justicia de la Nación (SCJN), desechó la acción de inconstitucionalidad que promovió el Instituto Nacional Electoral (INE) para impugnar las reformas a la Constitución de Baja California, con la que se amplió de 2 a 5 años el periodo de gobierno de Jaime Bonilla.
Con esta decisión, a la fecha suman siete los medios de control constitucional que se interpusieron para impugnar la Ley Bonilla, mismos que ya fueron admitidos a trámite por el ministro González Salas.
   •  Olga Sánchez sí sabía de la cámara: Bonilla
Cabe destacar que seis acciones de inconstitucionalidad fueron promovidas por el PRI, PAN, PRD, Movimiento Ciudadano, el Partido de Baja California y la Comisión Nacional de los Derechos Humanos, a las que se suma la controversia constitucional que interpuso la administración del exgobernador Francisco Vega de la Madrid.

NOTAS RELACIONADAS
text:
SCJN dismisses INE unconstitutionality action against Bonilla Law
For "notorious and manifest inadmissibility," Minister Fernando Franco dismissed the INE's appeal
06 Nov 2019 by Carlos Lara | The sun of Mexico
For "notorious and manifest inadmissibility," Fernando Franco González Salas, minister of the Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation (SCJN), dismissed the unconstitutionality action promoted by the National Electoral Institute (INE) to challenge the reforms to the Constitution of Baja California, with which the period of government of Jaime Bonilla was extended from 2 to 5 years.
With this decision, to date there are seven means of constitutional control that were filed to challenge the Bonilla Law, which were already admitted for processing by Minister González Salas.
• Olga Sánchez did know about the camera: Bonilla
It should be noted that six actions of unconstitutionality were promoted by the PRI, PAN, PRD, Citizen Movement, the Baja California Party and the National Human Rights Commission, to which the constitutional controversy brought by the administration of former Governor Francisco Vega from Madrid.
